data.current_description:
Once the certificate order has been created, this method can be used to check the status of the certificate. This method can also be used to retrieve details of the certificate.
  • **shopperId** is **not the same** as **customerId**. **shopperId** is a number of max length 10 digits (*ex:* 1234567890) whereas **customerId** is a UUIDv4 (*ex:* 295e3bc3-b3b9-4d95-aae5-ede41a994d13)
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the current status and detailed information for a certificate order. Use this endpoint to check certificate provisioning progress, view certificate properties, and access certificate metadata. Returns a Certificate object containing status, validity dates, domain information, and other certificate details. Note: customerId is a UUIDv4 identifier (distinct from shopperId, which is a numeric value).
data.reasoning: Original summary is generic and doesn't convey dual purpose (status checking and detail retrieval). Description is repetitive and unclear about what is actually returned. The shopperId/customerId distinction is important but buried in HTML. Improved version clarifies the operation's dual purpose, specifies the return type (Certificate object), and elevates the parameter distinction for better AI agent understanding.

message: Operation 'certificate_reissue' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_context, missing_output_details, poor_ai_interpretability. Summary is too narrow (doesn't mention rekeying option). Description is verbose with HTML tags and lacks clear structure. Reorganized to clarify the two reissue modes, prerequisites, validation behavior, and return value. Removed HTML formatting for better AI agent parsing.

data.current_description: Rekeying is the process by which the private and public key is changed for a certificate. It is a simplified reissue,where only the CSR is changed. Reissuing is the process by which domain names are added or removed from a certificate.Once a request is validated and approved, the certificate will be reissued with the new common name and sans specified. Unlimited reissues are available during the lifetime of the certificate.New names added to a certificate that do not share the base domain of the common name may take additional time to validate. If this API call is made before a previous pending reissue has been validated and issued, the previous reissue request is automatically rejected and replaced with the current request.
data.summary_suggestion: Reissue certificate with new domains or key
data.description_suggestion: Reissues an active certificate to change the private/public key (rekeying) or modify domain names (add/remove SANs). Supports two modes: rekeying (CSR change only) or domain modification (common name and SANs). After validation and approval, the certificate is reissued with the specified changes. Unlimited reissues are available during the certificate lifetime. New domains not sharing the base domain may require additional validation time. If a previous reissue is pending, this request automatically replaces it. Returns the reissue request status and details.
data.reasoning: Summary is too narrow (doesn't mention rekeying option). Description is verbose with HTML tags and lacks clear structure. Reorganized to clarify the two reissue modes, prerequisites, validation behavior, and return value. Removed HTML formatting for better AI agent parsing.

message: Operation 'certificate_create' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Original summary 'Create a pending order for certificate' is grammatically awkward and doesn't emphasize the asynchronous nature. Description is overly technical and doesn't clearly state what is returned or the side effects. Improved version clarifies the 202 response, explains both tracking methods upfront, and specifies the input schema requirement for better AI agent understanding.

data.current_summary: Create a pending order for certificate
data.current_description: Creating a certificate order can be a long running asynchronous operation in the PKI workflow. The PKI API supports 2 options for getting the completion stateful actions for this asynchronous operations: 1) by polling operations -- see /v1/certificates/{certificateId}/actions 2) via WebHook style callback -- see '/v1/certificates/{certificateId}/callback'.
data.summary_suggestion: Create a new certificate order asynchronously
data.description_suggestion: Creates a new certificate order and initiates the PKI workflow. This is an asynchronous operation that returns a 202 Accepted response with a certificate ID. The operation's completion status can be tracked via two methods: (1) polling the /v1/certificates/{certificateId}/actions endpoint for stateful actions, or (2) registering a webhook callback at /v1/certificates/{certificateId}/callback to receive POST notifications. The request body must conform to the CertificateCreate schema.
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Create a pending order for certificate' is grammatically awkward and doesn't emphasize the asynchronous nature. Description is overly technical and doesn't clearly state what is returned or the side effects. Improved version clarifies the 202 response, explains both tracking methods upfront, and specifies the input schema requirement for better AI agent understanding.

message: Operation 'certificate_renew' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Original summary is too generic. Description is verbose but lacks clarity on outputs and state changes. Added specific eligibility window, explicit mention of required SAN handling, and clarified return value for better AI agent understanding of when to use this operation and what to expect.

data.current_description: Renewal is the process by which the validity of a certificate is extended. Renewal is only available 60 days prior to expiration of the previous certificate and 30 days after the expiration of the previous certificate. The renewal supports modifying a set of the original certificate order information. Once a request is validated and approved, the certificate will be issued with extended validity. Since subject alternative names can be removed during a renewal, we require that you provide the subject alternative names you expect in the renewed certificate. New names added to a certificate that do not share the base domain of the common name may take additional time to validate.
data.summary_suggestion: Extend certificate validity with optional modifications
data.description_suggestion: Extends the validity period of an active certificate by reissuing it with a new expiration date. Available 60 days before or 30 days after certificate expiration. Supports modifying certificate order information including subject alternative names (SANs). All SANs must be explicitly provided in the request as removals are permitted during renewal. New SANs not sharing the base domain may require additional validation time. Returns the renewed certificate with extended validity upon approval.
data.reasoning: Original summary is too generic. Description is verbose but lacks clarity on outputs and state changes. Added specific eligibility window, explicit mention of required SAN handling, and clarified return value for better AI agent understanding of when to use this operation and what to expect.

message: Operation 'certificate_revoke' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Summary lacks specificity about permanence. Enhanced to clarify irreversibility, error conditions, and return behavior for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description: Use revoke call to revoke an active certificate, if the certificate has not been issued a 404 response will be returned.
data.description_suggestion: Revokes an active certificate, permanently invalidating it and preventing further use. The certificate must have been issued; attempting to revoke an unissued certificate returns a 404 error. Once revoked, the certificate cannot be restored. Returns confirmation of revocation upon success.
data.reasoning: Summary lacks specificity about permanence. Description is minimal and doesn't explain side effects (permanent invalidation) or what success looks like. Enhanced to clarify irreversibility, error conditions, and return behavior for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description: Retrieves site seal information for an issued certificate. A site seal is a graphic that certificate purchasers can embed on their website to display SSL certificate details to visitors. When visitors click the site seal image, a pop-up displays detailed certificate information. The site seal token links the graphic to the appropriate certificate details pop-up. Site seal images are static and hosted on the reseller's website to optimize page load times.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve site seal token and configuration
data.reasoning: Summary is too vague ('Get Site seal'). Improved to be more specific about what is retrieved (token and configuration). Description is comprehensive and explains purpose, usage, and technical context well. Only summary needed improvement for AI agent clarity.

data.current_description: Domain control is a means for verifying the domain included in the certificate order. This resource is useful for resellers that control the domains for their customers, and can expedite the verification process. See https://www.godaddy.com/help/verifying-your-domain-ownership-for-ssl-certificate-requests-html-or-dns-7452
data.description_suggestion: Verifies domain control for a certificate order, confirming ownership of the domain(s) included in the certificate. Particularly useful for resellers managing customer domains, allowing them to expedite the verification process on behalf of customers. Upon successful verification, the certificate order progresses toward issuance. Returns verification status and any required next steps.

data.current_description:
This method can be used to retrieve a list of certificates for a specified customer.

data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a list of all certificates associated with a specified customer. Returns certificate details including status, domains, validity dates, and other metadata. Ensure the correct identifier type is used in the request.
